pullRequest.title: KAFKA-9955: Prevent SinkTask::close from shadowing other exceptions
pullRequest.bodyText:
Catches exceptions from WorkerSinkTask::closePartitions call
If two exceptions are thrown the closePartitions exception is suppressed
Add unit test that throws exceptions in put and close to verify that
the exception from put is propagated out of WorkerSinkTask::execute

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris gregh@confluent.io
Committer Checklist (excluded from commit message)

 Verify design and implementation
 Verify test coverage and CI build status
 Verify documentation (including upgrade notes)

commit.message:
KAFKA-9955: Prevent SinkTask::close from shadowing other exceptions

* Catches exceptions from SinkTask::close call in WorkerSinkTask
* Logs exception at ERROR level but does not propagate exception upward
* Add unit test that throws exceptions in put and close to verify that
  the exception from put is propagated out of WorkerSinkTask::execute

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

afterCommit.message:
KAFKA-9955: Prevent SinkTask::close from shadowing other exceptions

* Catches exceptions from SinkTask::close call in WorkerSinkTask
* Logs exception at ERROR level but does not propagate exception upward
* Add unit test that throws exceptions in put and close to verify that
  the exception from put is propagated out of WorkerSinkTask::execute

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

commit.message:
Move error handling for close exceptions up to WorkerSinkTask::execute

This avoids swallowing exceptions that would have stopped the task in absence of an exception from start or put.

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Remove unnecessary checkstyle suppression

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Move test from ErrorHandlingTaskTest to WorkerSinkTaskTest

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Format whitespace and add comments

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

nodes.bodyText: If we're going to refer to this later while making assertions, a more descriptive name might help readability. Something like putFailure here and closeFailure below, maybe?

The call to fail() above is going to get caught here, isn't it? Think that might make this difficult to debug if a future change causes this to fail for some reason.
Based on the deliverMessages method where SinkTask::put is invoked, it looks like we might be able to narrow this down to a ConnectException.
Might be better to use this text as the message for the assertions instead of putting it here as a comment?

commit.message:
Catch only ConnectException and improve assertions on thrown exceptions

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Move verifyAll back to catch statement to avoid shadowing test exceptions

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Add message to fail call

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

nodes.bodyText: I am not sure I understand how the suppressed exception is logged and not just silently swallowed? Do we need to call  getSuppressed and log those somewhere or use one of those closeQuietly methods on Utils?

Again naming here can be misleading. ignored is more like unused in the try block.
But also that's not the point of this idiom. It's about suppressing exceptions from finally instead of the originator.
How about suppressible? Also, unused might be even better, because ignored is untrue especially if closePartitions is the only method that throws. But I think suppressible highlights the intentions here specifically.

Can you also write a test where an exception is thrown only by sinkTask.close? Actually, we could keep the name for this new test here as is, and the new test could be named in a way that tells us that the exceptions on close are suppressed in the presence of exceptions in the main try block.

commit.message:
Rename QuietClosable to UncheckedCloseable

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Rename ignored to suppressible

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

Add test for exceptions thrown only from close

Signed-off-by: Greg Harris <gregh@confluent.io>

nodes.bodyText:
Although I dig supressible with 1 p, like "sup? exception what are you up to?"
I'm afraid I'll have to abide by the usual rules and recommend: suppressible here 😄
(probably the IDE will complain about a typo too).
